39228.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 6.10, pagghari describes the bursting open of boils, from which pus and blood ooze out. While the basic meaning of paggharati is "to drip, trickle, ooze", in this narrative context pagghari specifically refers to the bursting or splitting open of the boils, leading to the oozing of bodily fluids. The aorist form indicates a completed action in the past.
39228.sutta_1: sāsapamattiyo hutvā muggamattiyo ahesuṃ, muggamattiyo hutvā kalāyamattiyo ahesuṃ, kalāyamattiyo hutvā kolaṭṭhimattiyo ahesuṃ, kolaṭṭhimattiyo hutvā kolamattiyo ahesuṃ, kolamattiyo hutvā āmalakamattiyo ahesuṃ, āmalakamattiyo hutvā beluvasalāṭukamattiyo ahesuṃ, beluvasalāṭukamattiyo hutvā billamattiyo ahesuṃ, billamattiyo hutvā pabhijjiṃsu. pubbañca lohitañca pagghariṃsu.
39228.example_1: The boils grew to the size of mung beans, then chickpeas, then jujube seeds, then jujubes, then myrobalans, then unripe wood-apples, then ripe wood-apples. Finally they burst open, and pus and blood oozed out.

11260.meaning_1: having harboured animosity (towards); having resented; having loathed
11260.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The absolutive āghātetvā expresses the action of having harboured animosity or resentment. In the given context from SN 6.10:2.5, it describes the mental state of Kokālika bhikkhu who, having harboured resentment towards Sāriputta and Moggallāna, was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell. The literal meaning "having struck here" metaphorically conveys the emotional "striking" of hostility or ill-will towards others.
11260.sutta_1: kālaṅkato ca kokāliko bhikkhu padumaṃ nirayaṃ upapajji sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṃ āghātetvā.
11260.example_1: He was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

22044.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
kīvadīgha 是一个疑问形容词，用于询问长度或时间的长短。在 SN6.10:5.2 中，它用来询问“在粉莲花地狱中的寿命有多长？”，表示对时间长度的疑问。
22044.sutta_1: “kīvadīghaṃ nu kho, bhante, padume niraye āyuppamāṇan”ti?
22044.example_1: “Sir, how long is the lifespan in the Pink Lotus hell?”

69938.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word vīsatikhārika is used in a simile in SN 6.10 to describe a Kosalan load of sesame seed measuring twenty khāri (a unit of measure). The term functions as an adjective modifying the noun "tilavāho" (load of sesame). It is a kammadhāraya compound where "vīsati" (twenty) qualifies "khārika" (measuring by khāri), literally meaning "measured in twenty khāri" or "consisting of twenty khāri measures".
69938.sutta_1: “seyyathāpi, bhikkhu vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho. tato puriso vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena ekamekaṃ tilaṃ uddhareyya;
69938.example_1: “Suppose there was a Kosalan load of twenty packs of sesame seed. And at the end of every hundred years someone would remove a single seed from it.

30833.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
tilavāha means "cartload of sesame" and is used in a simile in SN 6.10 to illustrate vastness of time. A Kosalan cartload of twenty packs of sesame seed is so immense that removing just one seed every hundred years would take an inconceivably long time to exhaust it. This underscores the immense duration of samsāra or the patience required in spiritual practice.
30833.sutta_1: “seyyathāpi, bhikkhu vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho. tato puriso vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena ekamekaṃ tilaṃ uddhareyya;
30833.example_1: “Suppose there was a Kosalan load of twenty packs of sesame seed. And at the end of every hundred years someone would remove a single seed from it.

7218.meaning_1: (comm) part of the Avīci hell where one must stay an abbuda-count in duration
7218.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 6.10:6.2, "abbudo nirayo" refers to the Abbuda hell, a specific hell realm in Buddhist cosmology. The comparison emphasizes that even a massive physical burden (a Kosalan sesame load of twenty packs) would perish more quickly than a single lifetime spent in the Abbuda hell, illustrating the extreme duration and intensity of suffering in this hell realm. The term "abbuda" in this context denotes a hell named after the immense, almost incomprehensible duration of torment experienced there.
7218.sutta_1: khippataraṃ kho so, bhikkhu, vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho iminā upakkamena parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, na tveva eko abbudo nirayo.
7218.example_1: By this means the Kosalan load of twenty packs of sesame seed would run out faster than a single lifetime in the Abbuda hell.

37997.meaning_1: (comm) part of the Avīci hell where one must stay an nirabbuda-count in duration
37997.meaning_lit: count of hundreds of millions hell
37997.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term "nirabbudaniraya" refers to a specific section of the Avīci hell in Buddhist cosmology. According to the contextual sentence from SN 6.10:6.3, twenty lifetimes in the Abbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Nirabbuda hell, indicating a progressively more severe and longer-lasting punishment. The word "nirabbuda" refers to a count of hundreds of millions, emphasizing the immense duration of suffering in this hell realm.
37997.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati abbudā nirayā, evameko nirabbudanirayo.
37997.example_1: Now, twenty lifetimes in the Abbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Nirabbuda hell.

37996.meaning_1: name of a hell; (comm) the hell where beings suffer from intense cold
37996.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 6.10:6.4, "nirabbuda" refers to a specific hell (nirayā) where beings undergo extreme cold. The comparison indicates that twenty lifetimes in the Nirabbuda hell equal just one lifetime in the even more severe Ababa hell. This usage aligns with Buddhist cosmology describing various hells with different types and durations of suffering.
37996.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati nirabbudā nirayā, evameko ababo nirayo.
37996.example_1: Twenty lifetimes in the Nirabbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Ababa hell.

7174.meaning_1: (comm) part of the Avīci hell where one must stay an ababa-count in duration
7174.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
Ababa is a technical term from Buddhist cosmology referring to a specific hell (niraya) mentioned in the Saṃyutta Nikāya. The contextual sentence compares the duration of suffering: twenty lifetimes in the Nirabbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Ababa hell, indicating it is a more severe and longer-lasting hell. The form ababo in the sentence is the nominative singular of the masculine noun, used as the subject of the clause.
7174.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati nirabbudā nirayā, evameko ababo nirayo.
7174.example_1: Twenty lifetimes in the Nirabbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Ababa hell.

1674.meaning_1: (comm) part of the Avīci hell where one must stay an aṭaṭa-count in duration
1674.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word aṭaṭa denotes a specific division or duration within the Avīci (uninterrupted) hell. In the contextual sentence from SN 6.10:6.6, it is used to illustrate the vast temporal scale of karmic retribution: twenty lifetimes in the Aṭaṭa hell are equivalent to just one day in the even more severe Ahaha hell. This emphasizes the extreme suffering and longevity of punishment in Buddhist cosmology. The term appears to be a technical designation within commentarial literature for a measurable unit of infernal time.
1674.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati aṭaṭā nirayā, evameko ahaho nirayo.
1674.example_1: Twenty lifetimes in the Aṭaṭa hell equal one lifetime in the Ahaha hell.

10864.meaning_1: (comm) part of the Avīci hell where one must stay an ahaha-count in duration
10864.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word ahaha refers to a unit of time in Buddhist cosmology, specifically in the context of hell realms. In the given sentence from SN 6.10:6.7, it is used to measure duration in the Avīci (uninterrupted) hell. The comparison shows that twenty ahaha periods in the Ahaha hell equal one lifetime in the more severe Yellow Lotus hell (Kumuda niraya), indicating a hierarchical structure of suffering based on time and intensity.
10864.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati ahahā nirayā, evameko kumudo nirayo.
10864.example_1: Twenty lifetimes in the Ahaha hell equal one lifetime in the Yellow Lotus hell.

22425.meaning_1: (comm) part of the Avīci hell where one must stay an kumuda-count in duration
22425.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
kumuda 2 refers to a specific division of Avīci hell in Buddhist cosmology. The contextual sentence from SN 6.10:6.7 compares the duration of suffering: twenty lifetimes in the Ahaha hell equal one kumuda lifetime in hell. This indicates kumuda is both a temporal unit and a hellish realm. The term is distinct from kumuda 1, which means "white water lily", though they share the same root. The hell-name likely metaphorically extends from the lotus concept, possibly suggesting a place where beings are "bound" like lotuses rooted in mud.
22425.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati ahahā nirayā, evameko kumudo nirayo.
22425.example_1: Twenty lifetimes in the Ahaha hell equal one lifetime in the Yellow Lotus hell.

51607.construction:
maha + nta + tara
mahanta + tara > mahantara
51607.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence "ayameva mahantaro kali", mahantara is used in the nominative singular masculine form meaning "this very great kalpa" or "this very important era". The form shows the comparative suffix -tara added to mahanta "great", but here it functions more as an emphatic superlative meaning "very great" rather than a true comparative. The sentence appears to be emphasizing the significance or magnitude of the current kalpa (eon or world cycle) in comparison to others.

58127.meaning_1: the Sanaṅkumāra Sutta; a discourse addressed to Sanaṅkumāra
58127.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the name of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 6.11), specifically in the Brahmā Saṃyutta. The compound is a kammadhāraya where "sanaṅkumāra" is the object of the discourse and "sutta" is the discourse itself. Sanaṅkumāra is the name of a deity (Brahmā) to whom the Buddha addressed this teaching.

58725.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term sappinītīra refers to the riverbank of the Sappinī river, a specific geographical location mentioned in the early Buddhist texts. In the contextual sentence from SN 6.11, it denotes the place where the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha. The word is a compound formed by the genitive of sappinī (the name of the river) with tīra (bank, shore), following the chaṭṭhī tappurisa pattern, indicating location or possession.
58725.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati sappinītīre.
58725.example_1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the bank of the Serpentine river.

34063.meaning_1: the Devadatta discourse; a sutta about Devadatta
34063.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is a title of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 6.12) that deals with Devadatta, a cousin of the Buddha who became a schismatic figure. The compound is a kammadhāraya where "devadatta" is the qualifier and "sutta" is the head, meaning "the discourse about Devadatta".

5895.meaning_1: the Andhaka Vināda Sutta; the discourse at Andhakavinda
5895.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the name of SN 6.13, the discourse delivered at Andhakavinda, a park in Rājagaha. The term combines "andhaka" (darkness), "vināda" (sound, noise), and "sutta" (discourse), possibly referring to a place name where the Buddha delivered this sermon on the nature of existence and the dangers of sensual pleasures.

5893.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
Andhakavinda is a proper noun referring to a specific town where the Buddha resided during his time in Magadha. The word appears in the locative case (andhakavinde) in the sentence, indicating location. It belongs to the semantic field of geographical names, specifically settlements.
5893.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā māgadhesu viharati andhakavinde.
5893.example_1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans at Andhakavinda.

61704.meaning_1: release from bondage; liberation from the fetters; freedom from that which binds
61704.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence "careyya saṃyojanavippamokkhā" from SN 6.13:2.2, the word appears in the instrumental singular form, meaning "with release from fetters" or "by practicing release from the bonds." It refers to the spiritual practice of freeing oneself from the ten fetters (saṃyojanāni) that bind beings to saṃsāra, such as desire, ill-will, conceit, and ignorance. The term combines saṃyojana ("fetter, bond") with vippamokkha ("release, liberation"), forming a kammadhāraya compound where the second member is the primary element. This concept is central to Buddhist soteriology, representing the goal of the holy life.
61704.example_1: and practice to be released from fetters.

54372.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term rakkhitatta is a compound meaning "self-protected" or "one who protects oneself". In the sentence saṅghe vase rakkhitatto satīmā, it describes a person living in the Saṅgha who is mindful and takes care of their own well-being. The word is formed from rakkhita "protected" and atta "self", functioning as an adjective in the masculine nominative singular form (rakkhitatto) agreeing with an implied masculine subject such as bhikkhu.
54372.example_1: live in the Saṅgha, self-protected and mindful.

22573.meaning_1: from family to family; from house to house
22573.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
kulākulaṃ is a reduplicative compound meaning "from family to family" or "from house to house". It is used adverbially to describe the movement of bhikkhus going on almsround, visiting multiple households in succession. The reduplication emphasizes the repetitive, itinerant nature of the activity. The construction shows reduplication of the noun kula with sandhi resulting in the final -aṃ. This type of reduplicative compound is common in Pāḷi for expressing repetitive motion or distribution across multiple instances of the base noun.
22573.example_1: Walking for alms from family to family,

13745.meaning_1: with faculties guarded; with senses protected
13745.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term indriyagutta describes a meditative or ethical quality of guarding or restraining the sense faculties (indriya) through mindfulness and self-control (gutta). In the contextual sentence from SN 6.13:3.2, it appears alongside nipako (alert) and satimā (mindful), forming a triad of qualities essential for spiritual development. The compound functions as an adjective describing a person who maintains vigilant control over their sensory engagement, preventing unwholesome mental states from arising through unguarded sense contact.
13745.example_1: with senses guarded, alert and mindful.

31422.meaning_1: makes thunder; causes to roar; thunders
31422.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
thanayati is the causative form of thaneti "to roar, thunder". In the context "vijju sañcarati thanayati devo", it describes the deity causing thunder to resound as lightning flashes. The verb is intransitive in meaning (the sky/thunder itself is what roars) but grammatically causative in form, showing the agency of the deity in producing the thunderous sound.
31422.example_1: where the lightning flashes and the heavens thunder

65219.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term sotasamāpanna refers to one who has attained sotāpatti or stream-entry, the first stage of enlightenment. In the context of SN 6.13:6.3, "sabbe sotasamāpannā" means "all stream-enterers", referring to those who have entered the stream leading to Nibbāna and will attain final liberation within a maximum of seven more births.

2265.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word atiracchānagāmī means "not going to the animal realm" or "freed from rebirth in the animal realm." It is a negative compound formed by adding the negative prefix a- (from na) to tiracchāna "animal" and gāmī "going." In the context of SN 6.13:6.4, it describes beings who are no longer subject to rebirth in the animal realm, indicating spiritual progress beyond lower forms of existence.
2265.example_1: freed from rebirth in the animal realm.

46545.meaning_1: having a share in merit; possessing merit; one who has participated in meritorious deeds
46545.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the context of SN 6.13:7.2, "puññabhāgāti me mano" means "those who I think have shared in merit" or "those who I consider to have a portion of merit." The term refers to beings who have accumulated or participated in meritorious actions, making them worthy of respect or offerings. It is a kammadhāraya compound where "puñña" (merit, goodness, wholesome action) combines with "bhāga" (share, portion) to denote one who has a share in merit.
46545.example_1: who I think have shared in merit—

18552.meaning_1: feels shame; feels remorse; feels embarrassed; is afraid (of)
18552.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
ottapati is a variant spelling of ottappati, showing gemination loss (pp > p). In the context "musāvādassa ottapan"ti" it means "for fear of speaking falsely", indicating the sense of being afraid or ashamed of wrongdoing.

9067.meaning_1: the Aruṇavatī Sutta; a discourse named after the goddess Aruṇavatī
9067.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The aruṇavatīsutta is a discourse in the Brahma Saṃyutta (SN 6.14) named after the goddess Aruṇavatī. The compound is a kammadhāraya where aruṇavatī (the goddess) modifies sutta (discourse), meaning "the sutta concerning Aruṇavatī" or "the Aruṇavatī discourse".

9068.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
Aruṇavā is a royal name meaning "having the quality of dawn" or "ruddy/dawn-colored." The name is formed with the taddhita suffix -vant added to aruṇa ("dawn, red"). In the contextual sentence from SN 6.14, he is mentioned as a former king, placing him in the family_set of "names of royalty" alongside other regal figures in the Pāḷi canon.
9068.example_1: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a king named Aruṇavā.

32673.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
dissamāna is the present passive participle of dissati "to be seen, to appear". In the contextual sentence from SN 6.14, it describes the bhikkhu teaching Dhamma with his body alternately visible and invisible, demonstrating supernormal powers. The word literally means "being seen" and functions as an adjective meaning "visible, apparent". It is formed from the root √dis with the ya suffix (passive) plus the participial suffix māna.
32673.sutta_1: ‘evaṃ, bhante’ti kho, bhikkhave, abhibhū bhikkhu sikhissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa paṭissutvā dissamānenapi kāyena dhammaṃ desesi, adissamānenapi kāyena dhammaṃ desesi, dissamānenapi heṭṭhimena upaḍḍhakāyena adissamānena uparimena upaḍḍhakāyena dhammaṃ desesi, dissamānenapi uparimena upaḍḍhakāyena adissamānena heṭṭhimena upaḍḍhakāyena dhammaṃ desesi.
32673.example_1: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied Abhibhū. Then he taught Dhamma with his body visible; with his body invisible; with the lower half visible and the upper half invisible; and with the upper half visible and the lower half invisible.

2904.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
adissamāna 2 is the negative present participle of dissati "to be seen", meaning "not being seen" or "invisible". In the contextual sentence from SN 6.14, it describes the bhikkhu teaching Dhamma with his body invisible, contrasting with dissamānena "visible". The form is built on the passive present participle dissamāna with the negative prefix a-.
2904.sutta_1: ‘evaṃ, bhante’ti kho, bhikkhave, abhibhū bhikkhu sikhissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa paṭissutvā dissamānenapi kāyena dhammaṃ desesi, adissamānenapi kāyena dhammaṃ desesi, dissamānenapi heṭṭhimena upaḍḍhakāyena adissamānena uparimena upaḍḍhakāyena dhammaṃ desesi, dissamānenapi uparimena upaḍḍhakāyena adissamānena heṭṭhimena upaḍḍhakāyena dhammaṃ desesi.
2904.example_1: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied Abhibhū. Then he taught Dhamma with his body visible; with his body invisible; with the lower half visible and the upper half invisible; and with the upper half visible and the lower half invisible.

15592.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term upaḍḍhakāya appears in SN 6.14 describing the Buddha Abhibhū's miraculous display of teaching Dhamma with different parts of his body visible or invisible. It literally means "half-body" and refers to either the upper or lower half of the body. The compound is formed from upaḍḍha "half" + kāya "body" in a kammadhāraya (descriptive) compound structure.
15592.sutta_1: ‘evaṃ, bhante’ti kho, bhikkhave, abhibhū bhikkhu sikhissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa paṭissutvā dissamānenapi kāyena dhammaṃ desesi, adissamānenapi kāyena dhammaṃ desesi, dissamānenapi heṭṭhimena upaḍḍhakāyena adissamānena uparimena upaḍḍhakāyena dhammaṃ desesi, dissamānenapi uparimena upaḍḍhakāyena adissamānena heṭṭhimena upaḍḍhakāyena dhammaṃ desesi.
15592.example_1: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied Abhibhū. Then he taught Dhamma with his body visible; with his body invisible; with the lower half visible and the upper half invisible; and with the upper half visible and the lower half invisible.

36730.meaning_1: goes out; comes out; leaves; departs; exits
36730.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 6.14:6.1, nikkamatha (imperative plural) is used as a call to action: "ārambhatha nikkamatha" — "Rouse yourselves! Try harder!" or literally "Begin! Go forth!" Here nikkamati carries the sense of "go forth, proceed, strive" in a figurative sense, urging effort and progress on the spiritual path.

43586.meaning_1: the Parinibbāna discourse; the discourse on final passing away
43586.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the name of SN 6.15, a discourse in the Brahmā Saṃyutta dealing with the theme of final nibbāna or parinibbāna. As a kammadhāraya compound, it means "a sutta about parinibbāna" or "the parinibbāna discourse", where "parinibbāna" means final passing away or complete extinction and "sutta" means discourse.

5894.meaning_1: name of a town; in reference to Andhakavindasuttaṃ
5894.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word andhakavinda is a place name, specifically a town mentioned in the Andhakavindasuttaṃ (SN 6.15). The contextual sentence "andhakavindo aruṇavatī" indicates it is being used as a proper noun in the nominative case, referring to the town itself. The compound is formed from "andhaka" (blind/dark) + "vinda" (finder/obtainer), though as a toponym the literal meaning may not be directly relevant to its usage.

8938.meaning_1: chapter of arahants; the first chapter on arahants
8938.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
arahantavagga 1 is the heading for the first chapter (vagga) of the Saṃyutta Nikāya, which contains suttas related to arahants. The term arahant refers to a perfected person who has attained enlightenment, and vagga means chapter or section. This compound is a kammadhāraya, with arahant qualifying vagga.

34551.meaning_1: the Dhanañjānī Sutta; the discourse addressed to Dhanañjānī
34551.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
dhanañjānīsutta refers to a specific sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (section 7) named after the brahmin Dhanañjānī, to whom the discourse is addressed. The compound is a kammadhāraya where dhanañjānī functions as the qualifier and sutt(a) is the head noun, indicating a discourse or sermon.

16160.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.1:1.4, upasaṃharantī (feminine singular form of upasaṃharanta) describes Dhanañjānī Brāhmaṇī as she is bringing her husband's meal, when she trips. The participle indicates the active process of carrying something towards someone, specifically a meal being brought to her husband. The meaning "bringing (to); carrying (towards)" fits perfectly with this context of physically transporting food.
16160.sutta_1: atha kho dhanañjānī brāhmaṇī bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa bhattaṃ upasaṃharantī upakkhalitvā tikkhattuṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
16160.example_1: Once, while she was bringing her husband his meal, she tripped and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:

66473.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The contextual sentence from SN 7.1:5.2 shows vasalī used in a derogatory sense, referring to a woman of low social status who praises a wandering ascetic. The term carries strong social stigma, reflecting the rigid caste hierarchy of ancient Indian society. The feminine form is created via the taddhita suffix -ī added to the base vasala, following standard Pāḷi derivational patterns.
66473.sutta_1: “evamevaṃ panāyaṃ vasalī yasmiṃ vā tasmiṃ vā tassa muṇḍakassa samaṇassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.

35715.meaning_1: does not take; does not accept; does not receive

35715.sutta_1: “evameva kho, brāhmaṇa, yaṃ tvaṃ amhe anakkosante akkosasi, arosente rosesi, abhaṇḍante bhaṇḍasi, taṃ te mayaṃ nappaṭiggaṇhāma.

9109.meaning_1: not causing anger; not irritating; not annoying; not infuriating
9109.comment:

The participle is transitive, taking an object in the accusative case.

The contextual sentence "bahumpi palapaṃ jappaṃ" shows it in the sense of one who mutters many prayers, aligning with the meaning "praying; muttering" rather than "desiring".

The term "aggikasutta" is a kammadhāraya compound meaning "fire discourse" or "sutta about fire", referring to this specific teaching on the fire sacrifice.

The sutta demonstrates the Buddha’s method of guiding interlocutors through reasoned inquiry toward the Dhamma. As a kammadhāraya compound, it literally means “Sundarikā’s sutta” or “the sutta addressed to Sundarikā”.
